TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
FOR THE 
 
REGIONAL CAPACITY BUILDING WORKSHOP ON 
 
PERFORMANCE-BASED ALLOCATION OF ADF RESOURCES 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
January 2005

  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  ADF  –  Asian Development Fund 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  IDA  –  International Development Association 
  PBA  –  performance-based allocation 
  RM  –  resident mission 
  TA  –  technical assistance

This report was prepared by F. Harrigan, Strategic Planning, Policy and Interagency Division, 
Strategy and Policy Department.

1
I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  ADB allocates Asian Development Fund (ADF) resources in accordance with its Policy 
on Performance-Based Allocation.  The Board approved revisions to the policy on 10 December 
2004 (“the Policy”). The revised policy requires annual country performance assessments for all 
countries with access to ADF resources and anticipates strong client engagement during the 
performance assessment process and in the subsequent use of ratings’ diagnostics for the 
design of strategy and operations. The purpose of this technical assistance (TA) is to foster a 
deeper understanding and ownership of the revised PBA policy among ADF borrowing clients 
and to acquaint them and other in-country stakeholders with revisions to the policy that were 
approved by the Board in December 2004. It is anticipated that this TA will be the first in a 
sequence of activities aimed at promoting deeper understanding and ownership of ADB’s PBA 
policy among DMC clients. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  ADF clients need to understand the operation of the PBA policy on three levels: (i) the 
nature of the performance criteria as well as the basis for and process of assessment; (ii) the 
framework for resource allocation decisions; and (iii) intended linkages between the policy, 
opportunities for dialogue and the design of country strategies and operations. Understanding of 
the objectives of the policy and how it works is also essential if borrowing countries are to 
respond  to the  incentives  it  provides  for  improved  performance.    The  public  disclosure  of 
country performance ratings, which will begin with the 2005 country performance assessments, 
may also place new demands on ADF clients to explain and clarify perspectives a number of 
challenges.  
 
3.  Early communication about the intent and purpose of the revised policy with in-country 
stakeholders in the private sector and civil society is also important.  Misinterpretation and 
misuse of ratings is more likely if stakeholders are ill informed about the objectives and scope of 
the policy. Additionally, if “outside” scrutiny and independent commentary is to help improve the 
quality and robustness of ratings, the existing framework for ratings needs to be explained.  The 
revised  policy  presents  opportunities  for  strengthened  partnerships  with  civil  society  and 
improved access to in-country information and expertise.        
 
4.  The concept for this TA emerged during ADF IX replenishment negotiations.  Borrower 
representatives at these meetings expressed the view that DMCs needed to acquire a better 
understanding of the policy and its implementation.  Donor shareholders supported deeper 
client engagement in the process.  In discussing the policy, Board members underlined the 
importance  of  clearly  explaining  changes  to  ADF  clients  and  to  civil  society  in  borrowing 
countries.   The TA framework (Appendix 1) reflects the views of these stakeholders.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
5.  The goal of the TA is to contribute to poverty reduction through the most effective use of 
ADF resources.  It seeks to do so by providing technical support to client ADF countries and 
other in-country stakeholders that will promote deeper understanding and ownership of the 
policy on the performance-based allocation of ADF resources.  This is a necessary basis for 
meaningful client engagement in the performance assessment process, connected dialogue on

2     
strategy  and  operations  and,  ultimately,  the  effectiveness  with  which  ADF  resources  are 
deployed.  
 
6.  The purpose of the TA is to establish in-country capacity that can support ownership of 
the PBA policy, and that will promote improved policies and institutions. The TA will also 
contribute to heightened public awareness of the basis for the allocation of ADF resources and 
will contribute to strengthened institutional accountability. 
 
7.  Key outputs will be two regional workshops.  One covering South Asia, East and Central 
Asia, Mekong and Southeast Asia developing member countries with access to ADF will be held 
in Bangkok, Thailand.  Another workshop for Pacific developing member countries (PDMCs) 
with access to ADF will be held in either Suva, Fiji Islands or in Auckland, New Zealand.  
Outputs will include a report on the assessments of participants, and a set of training and 
information materials on PBA.    
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8.  Each  workshop  will  have  two  modules  catering  to  the  differentiated  interests  of 
borrowing  clients  and  civil  society  stakeholders  in  the  PBA.  The  first  module  would  bring 
together senior technical staff from ADF borrowing countries, Ministries of Finance or equivalent 
counterpart agencies.   Each borrowing country would be invited to nominate two staff to attend 
the designated workshop.   The first module will be of two days duration. It is expected that 
participants would have the ability and be in a position to disseminate information within their 
home country. It is also expected that Resident Mission (RM) staff or staff from Headquarters 
directly involved in the country performance assessments would participate in these workshops. 
 
9.  The second module of the workshop will be of one day’s duration and will involve 
consultations  with  private  sector  and  civil  society  representatives  from  each  country.   
Participation by two representatives from each country would be supported under the TA. RMs 
will endorse nominations. Suitable participants may be selected from the media, academia, 
business associations, or institutions that espouse transparency and accountability. Participants 
should have an established reputation for independent commentary on development affairs. 
This initial introduction to the policy on the performance based allocation of ADF resources 
would subsequently be followed up in-country.  In-country consultations on country performance 
assessments and ratings would be led by RM staff drawing on inputs by participants. 
 
10.  The activities covered during workshop will: 
 
a.  Explain to relevant government officials the nature of performance based allocation 
systems. 
 
b.  Describe  and  explain  ADB’s  revised  PBA  policy  and  linkage  to  policies  in 
International Development Association of the World Bank Group (IDA) and other 
institutions.    
 
c.  Clarify the nature of the performance assessment and the role for country authorities 
and others in the assessment process. 
 
d.  Explain the allocation process and the uses of ADF funds. 
 
e.  Explain the ADF IX grants framework.

3
  
f.  Explain the nature of the disclosure procedures and the mechanisms that ADB will 
make available to country authorities to express their views. 
 
g.  Initiate consultations with developing member countries (DMCs) that will contribute to 
the mid-term review of PBA in ADF IX. 
 
h.  Begin consultations with civil society on a.–g. above. 
 
11.  ADB  professional  staff  from  the  PBA  focal  point,  will  take  the  lead  in  conducting 
workshop activities. Given alignment between ADB’s country performance criteria and those of 
the  IDA,  and  overlap  in  client  borrowers,  opportunities  for  collaboration  with  IDA  in  these 
activities will be explored. Consultants will assist in the preparations for the workshop and will 
support staff. A provisional agenda for each module is attached as Appendix 2.  Presentations 
would be supplemented by smaller break-out sessions and roundtable discussions.   Participant 
would receive a package of information materials and other relevant knowledge resources. 
 
C.  Costs and Financing 
12.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $400,000 to be financed on a grant basis by 
ADB’s TA funding program.  This will support the travel costs, accommodation and a stipend for 
participants, and pay for consultancy services.   The participation of RM and headquarters staff 
will be financed from the relevant administrative budgets.  TA cost estimates and a financing 
plan are in Appendix 3.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  ADB will be the Executing Agency.  The PBA Focal Point located in the Office of Director 
General, Strategy and Policy Department, will administer the TA, in close cooperation with 
operations departments, RMs and host country governments. It is also anticipated that IDA will 
contribute to the workshops. The TA will be implemented by ADB in consultation with host 
governments of each workshop location. 
 
14.  The TA implementation period will be from March 2005 to May 2005.  Collaboration with 
host country governments is expected to involve mainly logistical and protocol aspects of the 
organization of the workshops. The TA will engage an international consultant for a total of 2 
person-months intermittently over the project implementation periods and a total of 2 person-
months of domestic consultant. The international consultant, who has proven knowledge and 
experience in PBA methods, will be assisted by a domestic consultant. The terms of reference 
for the consultants are set out in Appendix 4. The consultants will be engaged as individuals in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  and  other  arrangements 
satisfactory to ADB for the engagement of domestic consultants.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
15.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering TA not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000, to be financed on a grant basis for 
Regional Capacity Building Workshop on Performance-Based Allocation of ADF Resources, 
and hereby reports this action to the Board.

10  Appendix 4 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
 
1.  Two consultants will be required, each for a period of about 60 working days, with one 
acting as team leader. The terms of reference is described below, with the team leader taking 
on the additional accountability of leadership, liaison, and reporting. 
 
2.   International consultant 
 
The international consultant will  
 
(i)  Prepare workshop presentation materials. 
 
(ii)  Assist staff in presenting materials at the regional workshops in Bangkok and 
Auckland/Suva.   
 
(iii)  Prepare informational resources to be made available on-line. 
 
(iv)  Supervise the activities of the domestic consultant. 
 
(v)  Coordinate with RMs on their participation in the workshops. 
 
(vi)  Collate participant feedback and prepare reports on the workshops.      
 
3.  Domestic consultant 
 
The domestic consultant will 
 
(i)  Work under the supervision of the international consultant in helping to prepare 
informational and learning resources for the regional workshops.   
 
(ii)  Will assist in the administrative and logistical arrangements for the workshops 
and provide support at both Bangkok and Auckland/Suva meetings.
